German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German nacht, from Old High German naht, from Proto-Germanic *nahts, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *nÃ³kÊ·ts. Akin to Dutch nacht, English night, Danish nat, Gothic ğŒ½ğŒ°ğŒ·ğ„ğƒ (nahts).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /naxt/
  • audio (Germany)
    		(file)
  • audio (Austria)
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

Nacht f (genitive Nacht, plural NÃ¤chte)

  1. night
    Die Nacht war lang und frostig.
    The night was long and chilly.
  2. darkness
    Sie wurden von der Nacht verschlungen.
    They were engulfed by the darkness (of the night).

Usage notes[edit]

  • In contemporary German, Nacht is used somewhat differently than English night. Although Nacht can be a general term for the dark hours of the day, when used as a time measurement it refers only to those hours when most ordinary people are in bed (roughly 11 p.m. till 6 a.m.). So while one says in English: â€œLet's have a beer tonight!â€, in German one needs to say: Lass uns heute Abend ein Bier trinken! (â€œLet's have a beer this evening!â€)
  • A (masculine) genitive Nachts occurs only in the phrases des Nachts (â€œat nightâ€) and eines Nachts (â€œone nightâ€) and alone as the adverbial genitive nachts.

Etymology[edit]

From Old High German naht, from Proto-Germanic *nahts (â€œnightâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *nÃ³kÊ·ts (â€œnightâ€).

Pennsylvania German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German nacht, from Old High German naht, from Proto-Germanic *nahts, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *nÃ³kÊ·ts. Compare German Nacht, Dutch nacht, English night.

Noun[edit]
